alert.note: Alert for Kittson (Minnesota) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Eastern ND and Grand Forks (Northeastern North Dakota and Northwestern Minnesota)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued April 18 at 11:51AM CDT until further notice by NWS Eastern ND and Grand Forks
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in North Dakota...Minnesota... Red River of the North at Wahpeton affecting Richland and Wilkin Counties. Red River of the North near Hickson affecting Cass County. Red River of the North at Oslo affecting Polk, Walsh, Grand Forks and Marshall Counties. Red River of the North at Halstad affecting Traill and Norman Counties. Red River of the North at East Grand Forks affecting Polk and Grand Forks Counties. Red River of the North at Fargo affecting Cass and Clay Counties. Wild Rice River (ND) near Abercrombie affecting Richland County. ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in North Dakota...Minnesota... Red River of the North at Pembina affecting Kittson and Pembina Counties. Red River of the North at Drayton affecting Walsh, Kittson, Pembina and Marshall Counties. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. ...FLOOD WARNING FOR SNOWMELT NOW IN EFFECT FROM WEDNESDAY AFTERNOON UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE... * WHAT...Moderate flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Red River of the North at Pembina. * WHEN...From Wednesday afternoon until further notice. * IMPACTS...At 48.0 feet, City dike patrol begins. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 11:30 AM CDT Tuesday the stage was 33.5 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage early tomorrow afternoon and continue rising to 47.5 feet Tuesday morning. Additional rises are possible thereafter. - Flood stage is 39.0 feet. &&
info.instruction: Safety message - Turn around, don`t drown. Don`t travel through flooded areas. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely.
